author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 27, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Students
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Safe Dining? Hard to Imagine, but Many Restaurants Are Trying
description: Though widespread reopenings may be a long way off, chefs and health officials have begun studying how a post-pandemic restaurant might look.
content: ATLANTA — This week, a restaurant here intends to sell what will likely be America’s first dry-aged porterhouse steak served by a waiter at a white-tablecloth restaurant in the midst of a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Coronavirus Briefings Offer a More Genteel Spin Than Trump’s
description: Downing Street’s daily updates are worlds away from the White House’s in tone, but they share a purpose: to control the narrative and deflect blame over a heavily criticized response.
content: LONDON — Each evening at the stroke of 5, a British cabinet minister and two expert advisers walk into a clubby, wood-paneled room at 10 Downing Street and take their places behind three socially distanced lecterns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: Gay Literature Is Out of the Closet. So Why Is Deception a Big Theme?
description: Until recently, gay literary characters had to hide their identities. But even now the closet — and the lies and concealment it implies — remains a surprisingly potent metaphor.
content: Near the beginning of James Baldwin’s 1956 novel “Giovanni’s Room,” the narrator, David, recalls the moment at which he became conscious of his homosexuality. He was a teenager, in bed with another boy — the bed itself a testament to “vileness” — and made what he calls a “decision” to live as a straight man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elspeth Velten
title: Out of Flour? Try the Local Wine Bar
description: In Brooklyn, some restaurants are operating as grocery stores.
content: Where there was once a collection of plants and a dart board above the wooden counter at Glou + Glick, a wine bar in Prospect Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, there is now a shiny new shelf stocked with pancake mix, kosher salt, tomato paste and hand soap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Trump Turns Shared American Experiences Into Us vs. Them
description: Nostalgia for a time when Democratic leaders could embrace Republican leaders in a moment of crisis — and when a bipartisan group would gather for an annual roasting in Washington.
content: WASHINGTON — Last weekend, an anniversary of the kind that would have once united the country in reflection — the bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, 25 years ago — passed without much in the way of comment. As the days inside pile up, our usual approach to a national moment of remembrance appeared lost to the fog of time, germs and Trump era news cycles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: This Florida Student Was Accepted at All 8 Ivy League Schools
description: Craig McFarland, the valedictorian of his high school in Jacksonville, Fla., received acceptance letters from 17 colleges and universities in all.
content: Most high school seniors hope to be accepted by their top two or three choices for college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Katie Ledecky Is Swimming, and Studying
description: The five-time Olympic gold medalist is taking an infectious diseases class at Stanford and still finding a way to train.
content: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff members, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley, Alan Rappeport and Emily Flitter
title: Small-Business Loan Program, Chaotic From Start, Gets 2nd Round
description: The Paycheck Protection Program distributed $349 billion in less than two weeks, but lenders and borrowers confronted confusion at every step.
content: One day before the federal government’s $349 billion aid program for small businesses was set to go live, the chief executive of a Minnesota bank was frantically dialing officials in Washington. Grand Rapids State Bank needed more time to understand the program, said the executive, Noah W. Wilcox, even as it faced a crush of borrowers. His pleas went unheeded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Paxson
title: College Campuses Must Reopen in the Fall. Here’s How We Do It.
description: It won’t be easy, but there’s a path to get students back on track. Higher education will crumble without it.
content: Across the country, college campuses have become ghost towns. Students and professors are hunkered down inside, teaching and learning online. University administrators are tabulating the financial costs of the Covid-19 pandemic, which already exceed the CARES Act’s support for higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Safe Dining? Hard to Imagine, but Many Restaurants Are Trying
description: Though widespread reopenings may be a long way off, chefs and health officials have begun studying how a post-pandemic restaurant might look.
content: ATLANTA — This week, a restaurant here intends to sell what will likely be America’s first dry-aged porterhouse steak served by a waiter at a white-tablecloth restaurant in the midst of a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan and Vanessa Swales
title: Governors, Facing Pressures on All Sides, Weigh Reopening Their States
description: In Colorado, Georgia, Oklahoma, Michigan and elsewhere, they face the same question: how and when to restart parts of their economies.
content: Facing the same competing pressures between keeping people safe in a pandemic and reviving some elements of a more functioning society, governors around the country Sunday made their case for steps they were taking — or not taking — to begin reopening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Trump’s Disinfectant Remark Raises a Question About the ‘Very Stable Genius’
description: The president has often said he is exceptionally smart. His recent suggestion about injecting disinfectants was not.
content: President Trump’s self-assessment has been consistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: To Pressure Iran, Pompeo Turns to the Deal Trump Renounced
description: The secretary of state is preparing an argument that the U.S. remains a participant in the Obama-era nuclear deal, with the goal of extending an arms embargo or destroying the accord.
content: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is preparing a legal argument that the United States remains a participant in the Iran nuclear accord that President Trump has renounced, part of an intricate strategy to pressure the United Nations Security Council to extend an arms embargo on Tehran or see far more stringent sanctions reimposed on the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado
title: As Coronavirus Strikes Prisons, Hundreds of Thousands Are Released
description: The virus has spread rapidly in overcrowded prisons across the world, leading governments to release inmates en masse.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prisons across the world have become powerful breeding grounds for the coronavirus, prompting governments to release hundreds of thousands of inmates in a mad scramble to curb the spread of the contagion behind bars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Global Virus Death Toll Crosses 200,000; Italy to Ease Restrictions in May
description: Boris Johnson is back at Downing Street and will return to work Monday after recovering. Cuba is sending doctors around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘He Continued to Stand With His Back to Me While I Awaited His Attention’
description: Seeking alterations for a new pair of pants, an exchange at a deli and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Draft Filled a Void, but What Happens Next?
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 26, 2020.
content: “We’ll go anywhere the science takes us and nowhere the science doesn’t.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Nicholas Kulish
title: Closed Hospitals Leave Rural Patients ‘Stranded’ as Coronavirus Spreads
description: A for-profit company bought three struggling hospitals in West Virginia and Ohio. Doctors were fired, supplies ran low and many in need of care had to journey elsewhere. Then the doors shut for good.
content: Michael Nuzum had spent weeks fighting coronavirus-like symptoms — a wracking cough, terrible chills, an exhausting fever — before collapsing at his home in rural West Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Padavick
title: How to Make an Illustrated Map in 8 Steps
description: Release your inner explorer. Here’s a way to relive, commemorate or envision a favorite place in the world by creating an illustrated map.
content: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York’s Leaders Elaborate on Plans to Reopen as Virus Death Toll Drops
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that construction and manufacturing businesses in less hard-hit regions of the state might reopen in May.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Sunday that after May 15, when his executive order shutting down the state is set to expire, regions of New York that were less hard-hit by the virus might be able to open construction and manufacturing businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un’s Absence and North Korea’s Silence Keep Rumor Mill Churning
description: Rumors about the North Korean leader’s health — and speculation over his possible death — have only increased over the past two weeks.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea is still sending letters and gifts to foreign leaders and domestic workers in the name of its leader, Kim Jong-un. Its news media brims, as usual, with panegyrical propaganda extolling Mr. Kim’s leadership. South Korea reiterates that it has detected “nothing unusual” in the North. President Trump has called “incorrect” and “fake” a report that Mr. Kim was “in grave danger” after surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Crow and Andrea Zagata
title: The N.F.L. Draft Pics You Haven’t Seen
description: In its remote broadcast format, the N.F.L. gave sports fans something to talk about until games begin this fall. Here are some of the most interesting moments, through the eyes of an illustrator.
content: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, did not get any hugs from the players selected at the N.F.L. draft this year, but the traditional draft day “boo birds” still made it onto the broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Koeze, Jugal K. Patel and Anjali Singhvi
title: Where Americans Live Far From the Emergency Room
description: In large swaths of the U.S., people have a hard time reaching a hospital that offers the kind of inpatient care needed to treat the coronavirus.
content: In large swaths of the U.S., people have a hard time reaching a hospital that offers the kind of inpatient care needed to treat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Steve Dalkowski, Model for Erratic Pitcher in ‘Bull Durham,’ Dies at 80
description: Known for his extraordinary fastball, Dalkowski never made it to the major leagues, walking batters almost as often as he struck them out.
content: Steve Dalkowski, a left-handed pitcher with an unimposing physique, spent nine seasons in the minor leagues without getting into a major league game. But just about everyone in the baseball world of the 1950s and early ’60s seemed to have heard stories of his extraordinary gift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: For Trump, Lying Is a Super Power
description: He will use deception to keep his bungled response to Covid-19 from ruining his re-election chances.
content: After Donald Trump’s ridiculous and dangerous suggestion last week that household disinfectants injected into people’s bodies might be a treatment for Covid-19, Republicans intensified their hand-wringing over whether his daily briefings were doing more harm — to his political fortunes and theirs — than good.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Kids Are All Right, Not ‘Coddled’
description: Young readers say their experience of life has hardly been easy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Summer Is Coming. Some States Are Reopening. Can We Keep Our Distance?
description: Nevada is one especially thorny example because of its dependence on tourism. But everywhere, faster and more widespread testing will be vital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, David Enrich, Jesse Drucker and Stacy Cowley
title: Large, Troubled Companies Got Bailout Money in Small-Business Loan Program
description: Companies with accounting problems or in trouble with the government received millions in federal loans.
content: A company in Georgia paid $6.5 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation — and, two weeks later, received a $10 million federally backed loan to help it survive the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Can Antibody Tests Help End the Coronavirus Pandemic?
description: The tests are not reliable enough to guide policy on lockdowns and reopenings, experts said. But they can help model the spread of the virus.
content: A survey of New Yorkers last week found that one in five city residents carried antibodies to the new coronavirus — and in that, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw good news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New York’s Leaders Elaborate on Plans to Reopen as Virus Death Toll Drops
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said that construction and manufacturing businesses in less hard-hit regions of the state might reopen in May.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Sunday that after May 15, when his executive order shutting down the state is set to expire, regions of New York that were less hard-hit by the virus might be able to open construction and manufacturing businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘That Sure Hits the Spot!’
description: Ed Sessa encourages us to hoist one.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — We talk about this concept a lot in solving, but anything I say here will be a spoiler. Enjoy this puzzle by Ed Sessa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaclyn Peiser
title: Needing At-Home Workers, Call Centers Turn to People With Disabilities
description: Companies caught short by the pandemic are hiring from a pool that was already prepared to handle a surge in phone traffic away from offices.
content: A workplace injury two decades ago when she was newly pregnant left Robin Irvin with neuropathy in her left leg and without a functioning bowel or bladder. She has been living on disability benefits since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Reopening of New York Could Begin Upstate After May 15, Cuomo Says
description: The governor outlined a plan to restart the economy, beginning with manufacturing and construction, and suggested professional sports could resume without fans.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — With promising indications that the coronavirus contagion has passed its peak, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York laid out a broad outline on Sunday for a gradual restart of the state that would allow some “low-risk” businesses upstate to reopen as soon as mid-May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Crow and Andrea Zagata
title: The N.F.L. Draft Pics You Haven’t Seen
description: In its remote broadcast format, the N.F.L. gave sports fans something to talk about until games begin this fall. Here are some of the most interesting moments, through the eyes of an illustrator.
content: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, did not get any hugs from the players selected at the N.F.L. draft this year, but the traditional draft day “boo birds” still made it onto the broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: For Pop Stars in Their 20s, It’s Totally the ’90s All Over Again
description: Every two decades or so, the old becomes stylishly new. And now the pop artifacts of the Y2K era — winking futurism, loads of glitter, “TRL”-style videos — are back, with an update.
content: The bright, aerodynamic video for Dua Lipa’s “Break My Heart” seems to take place in an indiscriminate time period — or perhaps just in the floating, eternal hyper-now of the pop music video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, David Enrich, Jesse Drucker and Stacy Cowley
title: Large, Troubled Companies Got Bailout Money in Small-Business Loan Program
description: Companies with accounting problems or in trouble with the government received millions in federal loans.
content: A company in Georgia paid $6.5 million to resolve a Justice Department investigation — and, two weeks later, received a $10 million federally backed loan to help it survive the coronavirus crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Summer Is Coming. Some States Are Reopening. Can We Keep Our Distance?
description: Nevada is one especially thorny example because of its dependence on tourism. But everywhere, faster and more widespread testing will be vital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Can Antibody Tests Help End the Coronavirus Pandemic?
description: The tests are not reliable enough to guide policy on lockdowns and reopenings, experts said. But they can help model the spread of the virus.
content: A survey of New Yorkers last week found that one in five city residents carried antibodies to the new coronavirus — and in that, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo saw good news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Marikar
title: ‘Heck Yeah, We’re Dancing’: It’s Diplo, Live From His Living Room
description: The popular D.J. is streaming music and memes to thousands with a fog machine from Target — and “having the best time ever,” he reports.
content: Around 10 p.m. on a recent Saturday night, the party really found its groove. Diplo, the D.J., songwriter, and record producer, was holding court behind a pair of Pioneer decks, wearing a Kermit green poncho and matching bucket hat, manipulating an undulating, underwater-sounding dance track with buttons and knobs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 26, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 26, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the artwork of the chef Ficre Ghebreyesus misidentified the area where he spent his childhood. It was in Eritrea, in East Africa, not in North Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Giants Draft Pick Andrew Thomas Is ‘Everything You Want in a Left Tackle’
description: Thomas, the No. 4 overall pick in the N.F.L. draft, described the opportunity to block for Saquon Barkley and Daniel Jones as a “blessing.”
content: Six days before the first round of the N.F.L. draft, Chris Slade, the head football coach at Pace Academy in Atlanta, took a phone call from someone in the Giants organization who wanted to know if there was any reason the team should not select Andrew Thomas, a former Pace player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles, Kate Kelly and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: As States Push to Reopen, Business Leaders Say Not So Fast
description: “Shutting down was hard, but opening up is going to be harder,” one C.E.O. said of balancing public health and a damaged economy.
content: Companies in a handful of states have begun taking tentative steps to reopen stores, offices and factories that were closed by the coronavirus. Yet as the first employees and customers return, interviews with roughly 30 major employers show that businesses are confronting deep uncertainty, and many say it is simply too soon to come back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirsten Gillibrand
title: Where’s the Nearest Bank and Ballot Box? Try the Post Office
description: The Postal Service should be allowed to deliver low-cost financial services to poor and rural communities. And vote-by-mail should be universal.
content: The United States Postal Service is an institution whose roots are older than the Constitution itself. Not only has it survived through snow, rain, heat and gloom of night, but it has also endured a civil war, two world wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War and numerous long recessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: In Praise of Pessimism
description: This country is going to need its Eeyores.
content: Confession: I have a secret talent for making lemons out of lemonade. It may not be readily apparent. I smile a lot and make cheerful conversation; my end of the dinner table is not some horrible event horizon beyond which all sunlight disappears. But tucked inside me, almost always, is a grumbling Eeyore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Not Enough Meat, and Too Much Oil
description: Jobs keep disappearing. Victoria’s Secret gets left out to dry. And do you know where your advertisers are?
content: Another week of pandemic news, another 4.4 million jobs gone. Here’s the latest from the business and tech worlds, plus what you need to know for the week ahead. (What day is it, again?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Chicago Bans Horse-Drawn Carriages Starting in 2021
description: After the City Council’s vote on Friday, operators will be unable to renew their licenses and the city will stop issuing new ones.
content: The steady sounds of clip-clopping hooves pulling creaking carriages will be absent from the streets in Chicago starting next year after the City Council on Friday voted to ban horse-drawn carriages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rod Nordland
title: Is the Light at the End of This Tunnel the Beam of an Oncoming Train?
description: A Times correspondent, now in New York, compares the fight against the coronavirus with other wars he has known.
content: Having been a war correspondent much of my life, I can’t shake the feeling that the war against the coronavirus is a lot like the real thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Volunteer Emergency Responders Face a Dilemma: Save Lives or Stay Safe
description: The coronavirus has overwhelmed scores of volunteer emergency response units, many of which are the sole responders across America.
content: In Teaneck, N.J., half of the town’s volunteer ambulance corps is out sick, in quarantine or staying home to avoid potential exposure to the coronavirus. The remaining 25 are responding to double the usual number of daily calls, racing from one high fever or respiratory distress emergency to the next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenya Slaughter
title: I Never Planned to Be a Front-Line Worker at Dollar General
description: No barriers, not enough staffing, low wages. They seem to not know there’s a danger to employees.
content: ALEXANDRIA, La. — I’ve been working at Dollar General here for more than two years. My manager is wonderful, and I have a great relationship with my customers. But when I took this job I never planned to become a worker on the front line of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: High School Sports Pushed Out of Bounds by the Pandemic
description: The cancellation of the Texas state basketball tournament hit a small town hard and reflected the wave of spring sports shutdowns in all 50 states during a normally busy playoff season.
content: The girls’ basketball team at Gruver High School in the Texas panhandle won its first state title in early March. A week later came the boys’ opportunity in this tiny agricultural community, where 400 acres of corn on the school farm finance college scholarships and sports provide a galvanizing sense of identity. Well-wishers parked along Broadway Street at dawn and waved as the Greyhounds’ team bus rolled toward San Antonio on a 10-hour trip to the state semifinals. Providing escort were police cruisers and fire trucks, their lights flashing, and a procession of semitrailers and galloping riders carrying flags on horseback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Wuhan, Kim Jong-un, Ramadan: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Two Weapons, a Chase, a Killing and No Charges
description: A 25-year-old man running through a Georgia neighborhood ended up dead. A prosecutor argued that the pursuers should not be arrested.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Ahmaud Arbery loved to run. It was how the 25-year-old former high school football standout stayed fit, his friends said, and it was not unusual to see him running around the outskirts of the small coastal Georgia city near where he lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Giants Draft Pick Andrew Thomas Is ‘Everything You Want in a Left Tackle’
description: Thomas, the No. 4 overall pick in the N.F.L. draft, described the opportunity to block for Saquon Barkley and Daniel Jones as a “blessing.”
content: Six days before the first round of the N.F.L. draft, Chris Slade, the head football coach at Pace Academy in Atlanta, took a phone call from someone in the Giants organization who wanted to know if there was any reason the team should not select Andrew Thomas, a former Pace player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles, Kate Kelly and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: As States Push to Reopen, Business Leaders Say Not So Fast
description: “Shutting down was hard, but opening up is going to be harder,” one C.E.O. said of balancing public health and a damaged economy.
content: Companies in a handful of states have begun taking tentative steps to reopen stores, offices and factories that were closed by the coronavirus. Yet as the first employees and customers return, interviews with roughly 30 major employers show that businesses are confronting deep uncertainty, and many say it is simply too soon to come back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Brad Pitt Plays Dr. Anthony Fauci in an At-Home Edition of ‘S.N.L.’
description: The latest remotely produced episode of “Saturday Night Live” also featured appearances from Miley Cyrus and Adam Sandler, among others.
content: Two weeks ago, “Saturday Night Live” returned to television with its first new episode of the at-home era: a collection of remotely produced sketches that were low on production value but high on spirit and innovation. It offered a window into what the show could do without most of its resources — and into the homes of its cast members, for those of us who always wondered what they looked like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: 32 Days on a Ventilator: One Covid Patient’s Fight to Breathe Again
description: Jim Bello, 49 and healthy, fell gravely ill, highlighting agonizing mysteries of the coronavirus. Doctors’ relentless effort to save him was a roller-coaster of devastating and triumphant twists.
content: HINGHAM, Mass. — “Is he going to make it?” Kim Bello asked, clutching her phone, alone in her yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Penny Dreadful: City of Angels’ and ‘Vida’
description: A new supernatural horror series and a returning drama highlight very different experiences of Mexican-Americans in Los Angeles.
content: PENNY DREADFUL: CITY OF ANGELS 10:10 p.m. on Showtime.  John Logan, the creator behind the fantasy horror series “Penny Dreadful,” which ended in 2016, follows it up with this spinoff. Set in 1938 Los Angeles, “City of Angels” delivers a packed narrative: A Mexican-American detective, Tiago Vega (Daniel Zovatto), and his partner, Lewis Michener (Nathan Lane), investigate the grisly murder of a prominent Beverly Hills family. Their search plays out while the city is building its freeway system and displacing Chicano families in the process. A shape-shifting demon inspired by Mexican folklore (played by Natalie Dormer of “Game of Thrones”) somehow ties into all of this, while subplots involving Nazi insurgents and police brutality bring the series, or at least its themes, to the present. “Even though our show is set in 1938, it has to be about 2020 or it has no reason to exist,” Logan said in a recent interview with The New York Times. “Race relations, social engineering, politics, espionage — all of that was bubbling away exactly the way it’s bubbling away now.” The series finale of HOMELAND leads in at 9 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Kirsten Luce
title: One Rich N.Y. Hospital Got Warren Buffett’s Help. This One Got Duct Tape.
description: The inequities of New York City’s health care system are clear at a public hospital in a section of Brooklyn hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: It has been hours since the 71-year-old man in Room 3 of the intensive care unit succumbed to Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus. His body has been cleaned, packed in an orange bag and covered in a white sheet, but the overextended transport team from the morgue has yet to arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: There’s Really Only One Way to Reopen the Economy
description: The way forward in the coronavirus crisis keeps getting framed as a false choice between saving lives or the economy.
content: The way forward in the coronavirus crisis keeps getting framed as a choice between saving lives or saving the economy. It’s a false choice. The only way to save the economy is to take the steps that will also save lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eaton, Anne Borden King, Emma Dalmayne and Amanda Seigler
title: Trump Suggested ‘Injecting’ Disinfectant to Cure Coronavirus? We’re Not Surprised
description: False “bleach cures” have been touted for autism, cancer — and now Covid-19.
content: At a news conference on Thursday, President Trump surprised nearly everyone when he suggested using powerful cleaning agents, through an injection, as a possible Covid-19 cure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Betsy Wyeth, Andrew Wyeth’s Widow and Collaborator, Dies at 98
description: She was just 17 when she met her future husband. She went on to guide his career and became an avid preservationist of vernacular architecture.
content: Betsy James Wyeth, the indomitable widow, collaborator and muse of the painter Andrew Wyeth, died on April 21 at her home in Chadds Ford, Pa. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Drug Approval: Holding Big Pharma to Account
description: The author of a book about the pharmaceutical industry discusses Gilead’s antiviral drug remdesivir. Also: No bailout for airlines; returning to the workplace.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jessica Murray, Joshua Sheppard
description: “We wanted certainty in the times of uncertainty,” the bride said.
content: Jessica Treanor Murray and Joshua Aaron Sheppard were married April 18 on the garden terrace of the bride’s parents’ house in Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Hollis H. Galgano, an Episcopal deacon, and a friend of the bride’s family, officiated. The celebration originally was to take place at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, a restaurant in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., before the coronavirus outbreak, and has been postponed there until later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Emily Herzberg, Samuel Dowd
description: The couple met on the dating app Bumble, and, boldly, spent their second and third dates answering “36 questions that lead to love.”
content: Dr. Emily Marie Herzberg and Samuel William Dowd were married April 25 at the home of the groom’s parents in Dennis, Mass. The groom’s father, William F. Dowd, officiated, having received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Reopening, Coronavirus, N.F.L. Draft: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By Ken Belson
title: Patriots Draft Kicker With Tattoo of a Militia Group
description: The kicker, Justin Rohrwasser, out of Marshall University, said that he did not support the far-right group, the Three Percenters, and also that he would cover the tattoo.
content: N.F.L. teams are sometimes criticized for drafting kickers, particularly if they take them as early as the fifth round.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: An Artist’s New Migration Song
description: Serge Alain Nitegeka can’t leave South Africa, but his art, on the refugee condition, is traveling.
content: Serge Alain Nitegeka hasn’t been free to roam in a while. For over five years, the Johannesburg artist has been unable to leave South Africa as he waits for his case for citizenship there to be resolved. (He was born in Rwanda.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: How Las Vegas Became Ground Zero for the American Jobs Crisis
description: As the U.S. economy has shut down, the burden is falling hardest on those least prepared to handle it.
content: When Valicia Anderson starts to count the people she knows in Las Vegas who have lost their jobs, she runs out of fingers fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Tang, Ethan Hutt and Daniel Klasik
title: A Constitutional Right to Literacy for Detroit’s Kids?
description: They deserve better schools, but the courts don’t offer much hope.
content: Already ravaged by poor health outcomes and joblessness before a crushing wave of Covid-19 cases, the people of Detroit received welcome news Thursday in the form of a long-awaited ruling from a federal Court of Appeals. In Gary B. v. Whitmer, a three-judge panel on the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals held that Detroit’s students enjoy a “fundamental right” to literacy under the United States Constitution. If allowed to stand, this landmark ruling could force the State of Michigan to dramatically improve the quality of education offered to thousands of Detroit’s most disadvantaged students.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Drug Approval: Holding Big Pharma to Account
description: The author of a book about the pharmaceutical industry discusses Gilead’s antiviral drug remdesivir. Also: No bailout for airlines; returning to the workplace.

author: By Pam Belluck
title: 32 Days on a Ventilator: One Covid Patient’s Fight to Breathe Again
description: Jim Bello, 49 and healthy, fell gravely ill, highlighting agonizing mysteries of the coronavirus. Doctors’ relentless effort to save him was a roller-coaster of devastating and triumphant twists.
content: HINGHAM, Mass. — “Is he going to make it?” Kim Bello asked, clutching her phone, alone in her yard.
